abstract.p: New York City Partnership to award bonuses to teachers and principals in six Brooklyn schools where test scores improved during 1998-99 school year (S)

block.p: After a long delay, the New York City Partnership is finally preparing to award bonuses to teachers and principals in six Brooklyn schools where test scores improved during the 1998-99 school year. After a long delay, the New York City Partnership is finally preparing to award bonuses to teachers and principals in six Brooklyn schools where test scores improved during the 1998-99 school year. The Partnership, a business group, began the bonus program in District 19, in East New York, and expanded it to District 23, in Brownsville, this year.

Board of Education officials said the awards were nearly a year late because state and city standardized tests, the basis for judging improvement, changed last year, making it difficult to compare scores. Teachers at five schools will receive bonuses of $1,000 because their schools were among the top 25 percent in terms of improved test scores. The principals of those schools will receive $5,500. Teachers at a sixth school will receive $2,000 each because their school was among the top 5 percent in its category. The principal there will receive $15,000.
